ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hearing aid malfunction due to moisture damage
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Physical inspection revealed rust and moisture; EAA showed excessive gain and high noise floor consistent with internal component damage from sweat/humidity.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Psychiatric auditory hallucinations
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out as 'voices' were indiscernible static occurring only when wearing aids, and symptoms resolved with device repair.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Radio frequency interference
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient suspected radio signals, but findings confirmed internal device noise and feedback rather than external signal pickup.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Baseline verification of hearing aid performance at initial dispensing.
Routine maintenance check to monitor performance stability over time.
Visual check for damage or debris given the report of 'hearing voices' and work environment.
Subjective verification by clinician to characterize the reported auditory anomalies.
Objective measurement of gain, output, and noise floor to identify internal malfunctions.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial dispensing visit. Hearing aids met manufacturer specifications and the patient reported the best hearing experience in 20 years.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.result_summary: Performance met specs. OSPL90 peak 124 dB SPL @ 1600 Hz; Avg Gain (50 dB input) 44 dB; Equivalent Input Noise 35 dB.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: 4-month maintenance visit. Patient reported reduced amplification. Testing confirmed reduced gain, which was restored to optimal levels after cleaning microphones/receivers and dehumidifying.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.result_summary: Avg Gain (50 dB input) decreased to 41 dB (from 44 dB baseline). Performance returned to baseline after cleaning.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: 8-month visit (Current). Patient reported 'hearing voices'. Investigation revealed moisture damage causing excessive gain and internal noise, mimicking radio signals. This correlated with the patient's high-humidity work environment.

tests.name: Physical Inspection
tests.result_summary: Accumulation of moisture and rust found in the battery compartments of both instruments.

tests.name: Listening Check
tests.result_summary: Auditorially very uncomfortable; instruments were amplifying at an unusually high output level.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.result_summary: Significant deviation from baseline. Avg Gain (50 dB input) increased to 54 dB; Equivalent Input Noise increased to 46 dB; Distortion at 500 Hz 7%.

proposed_items: Comprehensive cleaning and reprogramming of hearing aids to initial settings
Send hearing aids to manufacturer for application of internal protective coating
Purchase and use of electronic dehumidifier nightly
counseling_actions: Explain that the 'voices' are actually internal noise and static caused by moisture damage, not psychiatric hallucinations or radio signals
Educate on the impact of the work environment (heat, sweat, dust) on hearing aid components
Instruct on the importance of using the electronic dehumidifier every night to prevent recurrence

escalation.rationale_short: Issue is technical (hearing aid malfunction) and requires ongoing audiological maintenance and repair.

follow_up_plan.objective: Regular deep cleaning and performance verification to manage moisture accumulation from work environment.

expected_outcome: After comprehensive cleaning and reprogramming to initial settings, the patient expressed satisfaction and reported he no longer heard voices.
Hearing aids were sent to the manufacturer for an internal protective coating to prevent future moisture damage.
Patient purchased an electronic dehumidifier for nightly use.
Patient declined the use of sweat sock covers.
